div1.p: Your last letter has been on my desk a long time — I am incredulous when I looked at the date just now — 1956 — I carried the letter to Berkeley 2 summers and really have written innumerable letters in my mind and made a few beginnings on paper — why the block? I honestly don't know — especially when I tell you that letter writing seems currently to be my chief interest. And let me tell you I would prize a letter from you beyond anything.

Recently I began rereading your epics from the beautiful two volume edition you send me so long ago. It is a pleasure I have been promising myself for some time and I am
11b
2 happy to find that your poetry seems to me as beautiful as when I read it years ago the first time. It seems so carefully and lovingly finished and has a tremendous feel of the country and seasons and men — I shouldn't be offering literary criticism, not being experienced but I am simply telling how your poetry affects me — Later I am going back to the lyrics — a fine prospect for me to enjoy.

So you know Edith Hamilton's Hamilton's The Greek Way? We read the first chapter last night and are looking forward to more — Frank is not only a scientist but a philosopher who exemplifies his belief in his life and is altogether a most satisfying companion — It seems hardly just
11c
2 that I should have two perfectly happy marriages in my life when so many of my friends testify to the exact opposite —

Los Angeles is not an ideal home site but it can be endured quite comfortably if one looks for means of happiness — One of the best things about the place is the proximity of the ocean, the mountains and the desert — In the fall we make numerous trips to a high mt. canyon (5,000 ft up the side of Mt. San Gorgonio) where the apples grow — If there is time we make a two day outing of the trip and bring back apples and cider to enjoy for days afterwards. In December we always make have a vacation
11d
3 in the desert and again in the spring to enjoy the show of wild flowers—

The best part of Los Angeles for Frank is that there is a College of Optometry where they are glad to have him for a teacher, thothough he long since retired from Stanford for age — Here he can spend his whole time on research on the eye and teach young people — So, thothough my heart draws me to Berkeley where most of the children and grandchildren are living I know we shall continue in this ugly city as long as Frank can go up and down stairs and handle classes —

You must be in much the same situation in Missouri —
11e
4- Do they not have a retiring age in Missouri or have they made an exception for you?
We are in the midst of another hot spell and I am staying home quietly — usually on Monday & Tuesday, the days Frank teaches, I gad about and visit friends, but when it is so hot home is best.
